"That is going to be hard to control." Wincing, I said.

Jo Jo sighed. "Tell me about it." Frustrated, she said. "I suggest you and I join forces for now, to figure this hub out, and maybe help ourselves in the process."

I nodded. "It sounds like a plan to me."
11111111111211111112111121.title: The Hub is revealed.

111111111112111111121111211.content:
Jo Jo nodded, then gave a sharp whistle. To my surprise, another version of Izzy and Mina appeared inside my office. At that same time, my world's Izzy and Mina walked in and froze, seeing doubles of all three of us. "What...?!" We all blurted out.

"In my world, Mom managed to repair the two machines." Serious, Jo Jo said. "Only we still need to work fast, before what happened to us both becomes permanent."

The two Izzys walked up to each other, perplexed. "You are me..." In unison, they said. They then smiled and said in unison, "Jinx... you owe me a soda..."

Both Jo Jo and I sighed and said in unison, "Izzy..."

With everyone calmed down, we began to compare notes on what we were able to dig up on the device keeping the alternate universes apart from each other. Every now and then, Jo Jo would vanish, but my Izzy seemed to be able to see her clearly, as could my version of Mina. "That's interesting..." Thoughtful, Jo Jo said. "No one in my world can see me while I'm invisible, but your team can."

"They can't see me while I'm invisible,... can they?" Wincing, i asked.

"Let's try it." Serious, Jo Jo said. "Turn invisible, but only focus on that."

I nodded and turned invisible, though it was hard not to think of any what ifs. Once I had managed it, I turned to both teams and asked, "Well, can you see me?"

"I can." Jo Jo's Izzy said.

"As can I." Serious, Jo Jo's Mina added.

Both my Izzy and Mina shrugged, looking around. "We can't..." Softly, they said.

"That is so weird." Wincing, I said. I became visible again. "What do you think that means for any of us?"

"Nothing,... I hope." Darkly, Jo Jo said.

"I know that look." Worried, I said. "I've seen it in the mirror. What are you fearing?"

Jo Jo sighed. "That the device is beginning to fail..."
111111111112111111121111211.title: Researching the hub.

1111111111121111111211112112.content:
"Do we know who built the device?" Serious, I asked. "I'm not messing with anything if I don't know how it works."

"We looked into that." Serious, Nina said. "My grandmother was one of the people who made the device, with the help of a young woman named Finola Vimpir." She gulped. "She was a vampire from another universe, according to her stories."

"I think I've already met her." Wincing, I said. "We might need her help again." I knotted my jaws in decision. "Call your grandmother and see if she can come over. I'll have a talk with this Finola."

"Careful." Serious, Jo Jo warned. "If vampires are like what our stories tell..."

I gulped at that, then focused on the woman from my first jump and soon found myself again in her presence. Only this time, to my good or bad fortune, she was sitting behind a desk, with a tall and muscular man at her side. She turned to me, then frowned as the man fingered the hilt of a sidearm on a shoulder holster.

"We meet again, colleen." Flatly, she said.

I steeled myself and said, "We have no time for pleasantries... Finola Vimpir." That seemed to have caught her attention, so I continued. "The tenth level of hell is coming to both our worlds, and I need your help to stop it."

Finola was silent for a moment before she slowly rose to her feet. "Explain..."

"Criminals made use of a device to rob other universes of their riches." Serious, I explained. "Only it has weakened the device you and others had put in place, keeping our worlds apart...I was told you are among the only ones who knows how it works."

Finola sighed, raising a hand to her head. "I feared this." Shaking her head, she said. She looked at me, her eyes cold. "What is your name, colleen?"

"JJ Juspeczyk."

Finola nodded. "We have a version of you here... a quite annoying but useful self-proclaimed detective named Jay Jade, JJ for short." She frowned. "It will be interesting to see if she is jumping worlds, too."

"What do you mean?" Worried, I asked.

"My dear, the portal was opened the first time because meddling teens like yourself kept jumping to and fro, to meet other versions of themselves." Sternly, Finola said. "Consider yourself lucky that you are trying to close the device, and it was these criminals you spoke of who weakened it... otherwise..." She bared her fangs.
1111111111121111111211112112.title: Another jump.

11111111111211111112111121121.content:
"That seems to be a recurring theme." Wincing, I said. "We're all detectives."

"And, likely, all unable to keep your noses out of a mystery." Firmly, Finola countered. "How did these criminals get ahold of this device you spoke of?"

"Through blueprints stolen from our museum, according to my father's notes." Serious, I replied. I then briefly explained the chain of events and added, "Now, I seem to have the ability to hop between worlds, and my friend Jo Jo, from another universe, is stuck invisible, unless she concentrates on being visible."

Finola seemed slightly relieved. "That means that you two have become linked." More calmly, she said. "It creates a somewhat stable doorway, which will eventually close on its own, solving both of your problems... in theory, that is."

With that said, Finola turned to the man next to him. "Bring in Jay Jade. We need to determine just how bad this is, and quickly."

The man nodded, then left through an elevator. Twenty minutes later, he returned with a girl who looked much like me, only she was apparently a fan of early twenties detective stories, judging by the was she was dressed. She looked like a female version of Dick Tracy. "What mess are you cleaning up this time, Finola?" Frowning, Jay Jade demanded. "I'm in the middle of a mysterious robbery case."

"Let me guess..." Startling the girl, I said. "You are dealing with invisible robbers."

"Who are you...?" Surprised, Jay Jade demanded.

"I'm JJ Juspeczyk... from another universe." Serious, I explained. "If we do not stop these robbers soon, all hell will break loose."

"They are likely after the map fragments, just like in your world." Serious, Finola said. "I have the key piece here in my office."

"Then we set a trap." Nodding, Jay Jade said.

"I tried that and got caught." Bowing my head, I said. "That's why I can jump between worlds now."

"The devices are sensitive." Calmly, Finola said. "We will set a trap, but we will need more than the painting as bait."
11111111111211111112111121121.title: Meeting Jay Jade.

choices: I am trained by Mike Sutherland.
111111111112111111121111211211.content:
"You are not thinking of using us as bait, are you?" Nervous, Jay Jade demanded.

Finola grinned. "You overestimate your worth, colleen." Bemused, she said.

Jay Jade looked as if she had been insulted, only I caught the dry humor and smiled, which Finola noticed. "Are we in this plan you have?" Calmly, I asked.

Finola nodded. "This is an issue we cannot ignore." Serious, she replied. "Therefore, I will be staging a few tempting treasures for the thieves, and see if they take any of them to add to their growing collection."

"How will that stop them?" Wincing, I asked.

Jay Jade giggled. "Finola is in charge of confiscating cursed items used by vampires for their personal gain." Grinning, she explained. "It's actually how I first met her."

"You mean wit..." Startled, I asked.

"Not witches, those are a myth in this world." Firmly, Finola interrupted. "I am talking about items with superstitious roots which are widely sought out by the normals due to their history and stories."

"They also give clues of the Masquerade." More serious, Jay Jade added.

Finola nodded. "Once these thieves know who is guarding their treasure here, they will think twice before continuing or speaking of it."

"What will we be doing then?" curious, I asked.

"My... err... associate, Detective Mike Sutherland, will train you in the maintenance and protection of the gateway devices."

The man, Mike, nodded and slowly approached. "Listen carefully, girls." Darkly, he said. "You are in the big leagues now... fun and games are over."
111111111112111111121111211211.title: Finola's plan.

1111111111121111111211112112113.content:
I returned home what seemed like hours later, to discover that only a mere few minutes had passed. Still, I had full knowledge of how the device worked, and how to repair it, if necessary, and something to protect it. Finola did not give me much of a choice, a brief stab of pain and I had a strange tattoo on my neck...

"This is called a glyph." Darkly, Finola explained. "It tells those who know of it that you are under my protection. It also means I have the right to call upon you, if I felt the need for your detective skills."

"How did it go?" Curious, Izzy and Mina asked in unison.

"I know where the device is and how to repair it." Serious, I said. "It is this entire house, it emits a signal that keeps the doorways closed."

"So the smaller devices were used to open temporary doorways." Guessing correctly, Izzy said. "Only that put strain on the main device."

I nodded. "That's right, but a quick tweak can fix that."

"You let me deal with that tweak, young lady." Sternly, an elderly woman said. "I am Mia. Nina told me you would need help, but she did not mention you talked to Finola." She shook her head. "Pray she never offers you the Dark Gift."

"The what?" gulping, I asked.

"The Dark Gift is a ceremony where you would become a vampire yourself, and trapped in Finola's world for all eternity." Darkly, the woman replied. "I have a glyph as well but, thus far, no offer has come."

"So what do we need to do, Mia?" Curious, I asked.

"We need to first get your world-hopping friends home." Serious, Mia replied. "After that, we will stabilize the doorways, and teach you about parallel world law."

"Wait! What?!" Taken aback, I asked.

Mia showed me a badge. "Welcome to the fold, children." Flatly, she said. "Finola established a sort of guard to prevent worlds from colliding. Each group protects and maintains the devices."

"So we're the next generation." Sighing, I said.

Mia nodded. "You are, and I have no doubt it will bring many new cases for your J files."
1111111111121111111211112112113.title: continue.

1113.content:
"Is there a third option?" Worry in my voice, I asked.

"If you can think of one, we'd love to hear it." Serious, Dad said. "At the moment, I don't see any... err, no pun intended."

Then, to everyone's surprise, Grace waddled right up to me with a smile on her face. She held up her hands and squeaked, "Up?"

I giggled, then, without thinking, picked her up and put her onto my lap. That was when it hit me: Grace could see me! I turned to the others: Though they could not see the look of surprise on my face, they had the same expressions.

Finding her voice, Mom asked Dr Garrett, "How can she see her?"

"My only guess is that infants and toddlers can see things adults cannot." Surprised as well, Dr. Garrett replied. "There have actually been several studies conducted over the years trying to understand it."

"Well, at least you can see me, for now." Looking at Grace, I said. "That's something."

"It still doesn't answer the question: What are you going to do, JJ?" Firmly but kindly, Dad said. "I have a feeling that the longer this affects you, the harder it will be to find a way to undo it."

I sighed as Grace played with a necklace I had been wearing. "I don't know."

I then jumped slightly as the telephone rang. "Easy, pumpkin, it's just the telephone." Calmly, Mom said. "I'll get it."

Mom answered the telephone. Then, after a pause, turned to me. "JJ,... it's for you."

Who was it?
1113.title: Small blessings.

choices: They Think I Should Keep It Secret
They Think I Should Go to the University
11132.content:
I took the phone from Mom's hand, grateful that Grace indicated where I was. "Hello?"

"Hey, girlfriend," Izzy said. "I heard that the police caught a burglar at the university. Chalk up another closed case to The J Files?"

"I guess." I certainly didn't feel victorious.

"You said last night that you got an anonymous tip," she continued. "Did you get to see anything? Mina and I want to hear all about it."

"Oh, I've got a lot to tell you, believe me."

"Perfect. Mina and I are on our way. Mina's got an idea that's sure to grow the show. See you then." And she hung up.

"I doubt it," I said to the disconnected line.

******************************


By the time the girls got to my house, Grace had moved on from my lap. Mom didn't allow her a lot of TV time, but she still had her favorite shows, which she never missed.

Now, they didn't have Grace to tip them off that something major had happened, but they got another clue, courtesy of Mina's ever-present water bottle. She had needed a kidney transplant in junior year, so she had to keep hydrated. The thing was, she had a bad habit of tossing her dead soldiers aside, rather than disposing of them more carefully. On this occasion, she happened to throw the bottle right at my face, and I reflexively swatted it away.

Which looks a little strange, when the person doing the swatting is invisible.

Izzy was the first to speak. "What just happened?"

"That was me," I replied. "Something happened last night at the university."

******************************


After I told them about the burglary attempt and its aftermath, the girls had plenty of questions.

"Does it hurt?" Mina asked.

"Not by itself," I replied. "But sometimes, somebody throws a water bottle at my face, because they can't see I'm there."

"Can you control it?" Izzy asked.

"Not so far."

"That rules out my idea," Mina said.

"What was your idea?" Mom asked.

"I was going to suggest we get some video cameras. Get The J Files onto YouTube."

"Yeah, that's something that'll have to wait. I'm trying to decide if I should bring this to the attention of the university. On the one hand, they might have the way to make me visible again. On the other hand, they might want me to do things for them, or for whoever is behind their research into invisibility. What do you guys think?"
11132.title: one of my friends.

choices: The robber, he has to know something.
How an Invisible Girl Gets Around
111323.content:
"It seems like a risk either way." Wincing, Mina said. "Without the university, you may never be visible again; but then, the university may want something from you for the cure, if there is one."

"My question is, why was that concoction in the open in the first place?" thoughtful, Izzy demanded. "One would think the university would keep something like that under lock and key."

"Good point." Frowning, Dad said. "Only, for me to investigate the university, I would have to expose you and your actions, sneaking around campus."

"Which would be the end of The J Files." Sighing, Mindy said. She paused. "Unless... "

Catching Mina's reasoning, Izzy said, "Unless we act... " Softly, Izzy said.

"What's on your minds?" curious, Mom asked.

"We have to investigate the university." Serious, Izzy said. "JJ is invisible, and the university is responsible. If we don't act fast, they could take everything elsewhere, and we won't learn anything."

Dad sighed. "I don't like it." Annoyed, he muttered. "Only I don't see any other way. Even if I were to launch an investigation, the university could clear everything out before I get even close to gathering any evidence."

"You're giving us permission?" Surprised, Mina asked.

He turned in my direction. "This J File will be done under my strict supervision!" Firmly, he said. "You bring any and all leads and evidence to me before you act, and you keep your heads low! For all we know, this has government written all over it!"

"This is deep." gulping, Mina said.

"Welcome to the adults' table." More calmly, Dad said. "The stakes are high, and the danger is very real; so, if any of you want to back out, the time is now."

Mina and Izzy, though frightened, remained where they were, bringing a grateful smile to my face, though they couldn't see it. Dad nodded. "Alright, let's get to work."

"Where do we start?" Curious, I asked.

Dad grunted. "That should be obvious." Scolding, he said. "We start with... "
111323.title: They're Divided

1113233.content:
"... figuring out how you can get around safely."

I rolled my eyes, even though Dad couldn't tell. "I've been getting around on my own for some time, Daddy."

He turned in my general direction. "Let me ask you this, young lady: What does an invisible girl crossing the street look like?"

Ouch. He had me there, I won't lie. "I guess I didn't think about that."

"No, you didn't. But you'd better start. The consequences of thinking about it now are far less severe than coming up with something on the fly. And while we're on the subject: I'd better ask for your car keys. If I were still in a cruiser, I'd notice a car that seemed to be getting around without a driver, especially if it was obeying the rules of the road."

Another good point. "I'll get them later." Turning to Izzy and Mina, I said, "Guess I'll be bumming rides from you guys, until we can get me back."

"We'll all get to the bottom of this, JJ," Dad consoled me. "But it won't be just your show. We're all working together on this, the most important J File there ever was."

We sat around, brainstorming ideas for keeping me safe and undetected when I was out of the house. Among other things, we decided to restrict my activities to clear nights, so I wouldn't be given away by a me-shaped void in the rain, snow, or fog.

Grace's show was over, so she came to join us. Again, she made right for me, which still amazed us all.

Dr. Garrett left for her practice, and we had lunch. "I've been meaning to ask you guys," I said, "what does it look like when I eat?"

"Right now," Mom replied, "your sandwich is floating in the air, and, occasionally, bites disappear from it. During breakfast, the business end of the spoon would blink in and out of view as you ate."

"Well, at least I'm not grossing everybody out."
1113233.title: How an Invisible Girl Gets Around

11132331.content:
"So," Izzy asked, "how long before we break in and scope the lab out top to bottom?"

"There will be no break-ins just yet," Dad replied. "They'll be on the lookout for any funny business for a while."

"So how are we supposed to get the scoop?" I asked. "Ask politely?"

"There's more than one way to investigate, JJ," he answered. "I was thinking that one of you two girls could arrange a tour of the campus."

"With an unspoken plus-one," I said, catching on.

"Precisely. You'll scout the area in the light of day, perhaps even overhear some vital clues. Then, you'll report back to me, and I'll figure out where we go from there."

"It's perfect for me, Detective Juspeczyk," Izzy said. "It's my safety school, so, naturally, I'd want the lay of the land."

"Perfect, Izzy. You'll go, JJ will slip away, and you'll meet at a pre-arranged time and place."

Just then, my phone rang. "Oh, God," I said, "it's Nick."

"I didn't hear anything."

"It's too high for adults to hear," I explained.

"You'll want to put it on vibrate at the university."

"Duh." I answered the phone. "What up, Nick?"

"Nothing much, gorgeous," he replied. "I was thinking about somebody turning 17 in a couple of weeks. How does dinner and a movie sound?"

Dinner and a movie? Yesterday, that would have sounded like a dream come true. Now, however, it meant my boyfriend ordering for an empty chair, and sitting with his arm around nothing. "I'm afraid we're going to have to discuss that another time, Nick."

"What's going on?"

"Something happened last night, and I've got to talk with you about it. But it can't be done over the phone. You'll have to come here."

"Count on it, beautiful," he said. "See you then." And he hung up.

"Why does everybody say that?" I asked nobody in particular.
11132331.title: Our Next Move

111323311.content:
Dad had to go to the precinct house, so he wasn't there for moral support when Nick got there. "Where's the cutest girl in school?" he asked. It was a thing between us, like how one of his teammates liked to rest his chin on his girlfriend's head.

"I'm right here," I replied, walking up to him. That was my part of the ritual.

Of course, a big but unspoken part of the ritual was that both of us be visible. "Good job throwing your voice, JJ," he said. "Now, come out from hiding, and give me some sugar."

"I'm not hiding, Nick. I'm right in front of you. You can't see me because I'm invisible."

"It's a little late in the year for April Fool's, don't you think?"

I sighed. "Maybe this will convince you." I wrapped my arms around his neck, pulled him down to my height, and kissed him on the lips.

When I broke the kiss, Nick was wide-eyed. "Nobody kisses like you, JJ," he finally said. Then, he wrapped his arms around me. "Are you alright? How did this happen?"

I led him to a chair, and we sat down. "You know how, on The J Files, we've been investigating a string of burglaries? Well, last night, I got an anonymous tip that they were going to hit the Chem building at the university. It was a good tip, because he was there. Then, he panicked, and threw a beaker at me. It hit. I wasn't bleeding, so I got out of there. He got caught, and there seemed to be no damage to me, so I just washed up and went to bed. When I woke up this morning, I could see myself, if I'm looking directly at me, but I didn't have a reflection or a shadow. Then Mom came in, and she confirmed it: I was invisible. I can see me, and Grace can see me, but nobody else can."

"Wow," Nick said. "And you're sure you're alright?"

"As best as Dr. Garrett can determine."

"It works," he whispered. "It actually works."

"Whoa, whoa, whoa," Izzy said. "What works?"

"My uncle, my mother's sister's husband. He works in the Chem building at the university. And he told me he was working on a way to make someone invisible. I never believed him, but... " He gestured at the chair where I was sitting.

My head went reeling. The biggest mystery that I'd ever come across, and my boyfriend's family was in on it.
111323311.title: Nick

1113233111.content:
We decided to sit around, watching TV. Grace decided to join us; and, by us, I mean me. "How come she can see you?" Nick asked.

"I guess it's because she's just a little kid," I explained, "so she can see things most of us can't. I don't try to explain it. I'm just glad somebody can tell I'm here."

The phone rang, and Mom answered it. "Hello? Oh, hi, dear. Hang on, let me put you on speaker."

When she did, Dad said, "JJ?"

"Right here, Daddy."

"I meant to have a word with the burglar from last night, but the Feds got hold of him first. I almost hesitate to tell you the rest."

"Give it to me straight, Daddy. I can take it."

He chuckled. "I didn't mean it that way, honey. When I identified myself, the agent asked me if I was any relation to the girl with the podcast."

"That's my girl," Nick said.

"Did he give you any information, Daddy?"

"After I said yes, he said I could tell you that it was a petty crook who had heard from somebody that someone was working on a formula to make people invisible. Apparently, he had visions of stealing more, with nobody able to give a description or tell which way he went."

"How much of that should we believe?"

"I'm not willing to believe more than half. They play close to the vest in Washington. If they volunteer something like this, they want to see what you do with it."

"What do you recommend?"

"Pass that along on the podcast, saying it's from an anonymous source, and don't say anything suggesting that you believe a word of it. I'll bet they want to know if anyone takes it seriously."

"Alright, Daddy. By the way, Nick says his uncle is working on this project."

"Interesting. I'll ask him more later. I'll let you go for now, princess. Goodbye."
1113233111.title: Dad Calls

11132331111.content:
As the day went on, my friends started heading home. Not a problem. I was feeling better, even if I had no idea how I would become visible again.

After supper, I was in my room, working on the next installment of The J Files. After all, being opacity-challenged didn't change the schedule.

Frank, Jr., came to my room. "Can I give you something?" he asked.

I patted my desk. "Put it right here."

He put a piece of paper on my desk. "It's a picture of you."

I looked. The paper was blank. "You wanna know what makes antagonizing an invisible person a bad idea?"

"What?"

I flicked his nose. "You'll never see it coming."

Mom came to the door. "JJ, Grace wants you to read her bedtime story. Would you mind?"

And so I read her The Little Engine that Could, one of her favorites. For the self-important trains who wouldn't help, I imitated some of the men I'd butted heads with. For the Little Engine herself, I imitated Grace.

When I finished, I asked Grace, "You've been hanging around with me all day today, kiddo. Wanna talk about it?"

"You sad," she replied. "I no want you sad. I want you happy."

So that was it. She wanted to cheer me up. "Thanks, Grace. It's just, you and I are the only ones who can see me right now. It's pretty hard."

"Can you be seen?"

"Not yet. But I think I can." I kissed her forehead.

Back in my room, I finished the first draft when my cell phone rang. It was Dad. "Yes, Daddy?"

"Prince Charming's girlfriend came to the station looking for him," he said. "She said some things that make me think she was your anonymous caller. Which reminds me: From now on, I'm listening to your tipline."

"Gotcha. Did she say anything that might help us?"

"She said he kept talking about someone named Griffin. Sound familiar?"

"Isn't that the family on Frankie's favorite show?"

"True. But it's also the name of the title character in H. G. Wells's story, The Invisible Man."

"That would be some coincidence."

"And I don't believe in coincidences. Let's see how quickly Izzy can get in to tour the university."
11132331111.title: More Information

111323311111.content:
"Have a good day, Mrs. Kessler," Mom said, just before driving off.

"Thanks for the ride, Mrs. Juspeczyk," Izzy said.

"How hard was it to get her to agree to let me drive you?"

"I just said that JJ wanted to scope the place out, too. Which isn't even a lie, if you think about it. The hardest part was getting out to the minivan before she could ask why JJ didn't come out to say hello."

"Yeah," I said, "that's going to take some work."

******************************


As Mom pulled into the university, she said, "Now, remember: You meet back here in three hours. What's your signal?"

Izzy whistled a bird call, and I returned it.

"Alright. Remember, you're only here to look around and see what's here. Don't take anything."

"I won't."

"I think that's for my benefit, Iz," I said.

Mom stopped, and Izzy and I got out. Nobody was looking our way, so nobody noticed that the back door was held open rather long to let out one person.

Izzy went off to Orientation, while I headed back to the Chem building.
111323311111.title: Back to the University

1113233111111.content:
Once again, I was sneaking around inside the Chem building. This time, though, I had to be even sneakier. I had to wait by every door for someone who was either going in or out, lest someone ask why the doors were opening and closing by themselves. Luckily, a smoker got me in, and my work began.

As I approached the lab, I began keeping an eye out for any security measures that went above and beyond. I had no idea what the burglar had told anybody, after all, so I didn't know if they knew he wasn't alone in there. So far, though, the only thing out of the ordinary was yours truly.

Finally, I got to the lab, and I saw that they had installed a keypad entry system. Not a problem, I thought. I'll just wait for someone to come in, and they'll give me the access code for when I come back.

It took a good while, but a woman finally came to the lab and punched in the code. As I slipped in after her, I committed the code to memory.

Inside, my eye was drawn to the cages. When I was there before, I had seen the cages, but they had looked empty. Now, each cage held a mouse. When did they get these?

Then, the scientist began checking the cages. "No change in opacity," she sighed, then made a note.

That was when it hit me: the mice were invisible, just as I was. And, just as I could see myself, the mice were visible to me, now. Taking out my phone, I recorded video of the mice. The image on the screen confirmed that they were invisible. This might be important later, especially as the lab was working on a way to restore their visibility.

So absorbed was I in my own thoughts, that I almost missed it when the scientist left the lab. But I managed to slip out, and, waiting for other people at the doors again, I slowly made my way back out.

When I got to the rendezvous point, Izzy was there, whistling the signal. Even from 50 feet away, I could see her sigh with relief when I returned it. When I got to her side, I squeezed her shoulders.

"What kept you?" she asked. "I've been whistling for ten minutes."

"I was in a lab where they're researching invisibility," I replied. "You think I want to advertise my condition by opening and closing my own doors?"

"Sorry. What did you find out?"

"A lot," I said, as we climbed into Mom's minivan. "I'll tell you all about it at the debriefing. Trust me, there's more to this than meets the eye."
1113233111111.title: The Chemistry Building

choices: Nick comes for a visit and a talk.
11132331111111.content:
Upon returning home, Grace waddled up to me with her usual smile. "You o-tay?"

I smiled. "I'm okay, kiddo." Picking her up, I replied. "We have a lot to talk about."

I carried Grace to the table, where Mom took her. Soon, Grace was sitting in a booster seat, as we all took our places around the table. "The university had taken extra measures to ensure no one else broke in." Serious, I said. "That included a keypad lock. I managed to follow a woman in, where I found something... disturbing."

"Define disturbing." Frowning, Dad demanded.

"I found a number of cages with lab mice inside them, all invisible." Sadly, I explained. "The woman I followed in said, 'No change in opacity.'" I gulped. "There were dates on the cages, ranging from a few days ago to a year ago." I showed Dad the video I took, with hamster wheels and straw on the floors moving on their own. The video also showed the dates and scribbled notes on the cages.

After watching the video, Dad let out a low sigh. "The university doesn't have a cure for this, not yet." Softly, he said. "This makes keeping you safe all the more important."

"We don't want to see you joining those lab mice in a cage somewhere." Wincing, Mom added. "I'm sorry, but this is becoming too dangerous."

After a thought, Dad said, "JJ, I need you to go back to the university. I'll provide cover."

Mom was shocked. "What?! Honey,... "

"We need evidence." Firmly, Dad interrupted. "A short video is not enough." He turned in my direction. "We need one of those lab mice, so we have something to collaborate any claims when we eventually bring this into the light."

"I'll do my best, Daddy." softly, I said.

Dad smiled. "That's my brave girl." He sighed. "I've done some digging of my own, called in a few favors from other precincts."

"What did you find?" Curious, Frank Jr. asked.

"The novel, The Invisible Man, by H. G. Wells, was based upon the notes of a real person named Dr. Hawley Griffin." Darkly, Dad said. "Some agency had acquired those notes, and started Project Griffin."

"Named after the man who created the original formula." Softly, I said. "What else did you find out?"

"Well, as you had learned the hard way, they had a breakthrough." Serious, Dad said. "Other than that, all the other precincts are just as clueless as we are." His face turned dark. "There is one other matter."

"What's that?" Worried, I asked.

"In the novel, Dr. Griffin went completely insane." Serious, Dad replied. "It was a side effect of the formula he took."

"Only Dr. Griffin drank the formula." Pointing out, Frank Jr. said. "JJ was splashed with the stuff, so what does that mean?"

"I'm not certain." Sighing, Dad said. "All I am saying is JJ needs to keep her mental health in mind." He turned serious, "We can't see her, so it will be harder to spot any abnormalities in her behavior. JJ has to come to us if she notices anything out of the ordinary about herself."

"Dad, you're scaring me." Wincing, I said.

"We can't leave anything to chance, honey." Serious, Dad said. "Honestly, this scares me too, more than you might think."
11132331111111.title: The Debriefing

111323311111112.content:
Just then, Nick came in. "JJ? Where are you?"

"We're in the kitchen, Nick," I called out. "I'm the one in the empty chair."

He rushed in. "I had to come right over. Where have you been?"

"I've been scoping things out at the lab," I replied. "And now, we're working on my return trip. What's up?"

"You'd better be careful, JJ. They're on the lookout for Subject X."

"And I'm her?"

Nick nodded. "The guy told them that he'd had a run-in with someone. He couldn't give much of a description, but he thinks it was a teenage girl."

"And the FBI knows all about it, I'm sure," Dad said.

"The good news is," I said, "I always chalk up what I find when I'm sneaking to an anonymous source. I can find a way to throw them off my trail, now that I'm Nobody."

"I can help with that," Dad said. "We'll be all set for them."

I sighed. "The local university is teaming up with the federal government to try to follow me. That's going to make it hard to check myself for signs of mental instability."

"Huh?"

"Apparently, the first Invisible Man went crazy from his formula. And I'm the only one who can monitor my behavior well enough to know if I'm losing it."
111323311111112.title: Nick comes for a visit and a talk.

1113233111111122.content:
Mina tapped away on her tablet. "I think," she said, "I've got good news for you, on the sanity front."

"I could use it," I replied. "What have you got?"

"First off, when this Griffin guy made himself invisible, even he couldn't see himself. But you can."

"So?"

"That's a functional change in how it works," Dad explained. "Which means it might be less likely to drive you insane."

"Okay, that is good news. What else do you have?"

"Griffin's invisibility didn't extend to the clothes he wore. Yours does."

"Another functional change. Okay, things are conditionally looking up."

"Then let me put the cherry on the sanity sundae: Griffin experimented on himself."

"So his sanity was debatable, even before he made himself invisible. I knew there was a reason I made you my chief researcher. Brace yourself."

"For what?"

"An invisible hug." I wrapped my arms around her.

"I still want you to monitor your behavior, JJ," Dad said. "Even if you don't wind up crazy, you could still have psychological problems from being invisible."

"I understand, Daddy. You're not the only one who's worried about my mind." I tousled Grace's hair.
1113233111111122.title: Some Good News

choices: Dad gets a call from the feds.
11132331111111221.content:
Dad made arrangements with the dean of the college that night to run a routine investigation, so as to close his case on the robbery. "The chief doesn't like any loose ends in anyone's reports, and he is not a fan of the 'X-Files,' if you know what I mean." Calmly, Dad said over the phone. "I'm not trying to prove or disprove some wild conspiracy theory, just trying to close my report on a robbery and move on to the next case, so the chief will get off my back."

"I can certainly understand that, Detective." With a sigh, the dean replied. "The review board doesn't like to hear ghost stories coming from any university, it tends to scare away potential students."

The following morning, after a shower and breakfast, Dad drove me back to the university (where he took his time gathering things from the passenger seat, so I could hop out) and walked to the main entrance, where we were met with a young security guard. "My name is Don Roberts." Politely, he said. "I am to escort you to the lab and let you in. You have ten minutes to conduct your investigation before students start trickling in."

"Ten minutes should be more than enough time." Nodding, Dad said.

The guard nodded back, and opened the door for Dad. I slipped past, and Dad walked through after a moment, to give me time. "Something wrong?" Curious, Don asked. "You paused just then."

"I have learned from experience to pay attention to any noise that reaches my ears." Serious, Dad countered. "Ignoring sounds can be deadly in my line of work."

With that, Dad was led to the lab, with me following. The guard punched in the code, which I noticed was different from before. They're changing the code each day. Disturbed, I thought. Someone really wants to keep this a secret.

Now glad Dad ran cover for me, I slipped through as Dad again "heard a noise," and waited for the door to close and the guard to turn his back. Dad began taking pictures, which was my cue to take one of the mice from the cages.

Using vinyl gloves, I moved to one of the cages, to find the mouse backing away from me in terror, shaking uncontrollably at the very sight of me. Knowing I couldn't waste time, I moved to the next cage, to get the same reaction. Finally, a mouse came to the door upon seeing me, and I slowly opened the door. The mouse was cute, all white with blue eyes, pink toes and a pink tail. I gently picked it up and slipped it into a hamster pet carrier we purchased on the way to the university, then gently closed the cage door.

Mission complete. Smiling, I thought. Time to take this little fellow home.

I tapped Dad on the shoulder, telling him I was done, and he wrapped up his job of gathering evidence and knocked on the lab door. "I'm all done here." Calmly, he said. "This should be enough to close my case on my end."

"There are others running an investigation?" Curious, Don asked.

Dad shrugged. "The feds seem interested." Calmly, he said. "Only that's their issue, My concern is just with the robbery, as the one we caught said he wasn't alone."

Don nodded, then escorted Dad (and me) back to his car.

"Did you get the mouse?" Once on our way, Dad asked.

"Yup." smiling, I said. "He's a cute little guy."
11132331111111221.title: Back to the University

111323311111112211.content:
When we got home, Mom asked, "How did it go?"

"Perfectly," Dad replied, kissing her. "Did you girls get everything?"

"All here," Izzy said, indicating the supplies laid out on the kitchen table.

"We told the cashier it was for a birthday present," Mina added, "in case she was wondering why we didn't get something to put into the cage."

"Okay, then," I said, "let's get the cage all set, and introduce this little guy to his new home."

The cage was ready in minutes, and I transferred the mouse from the carrier.

"He's cute," Grace said. "What's his name?"

"I don't know," I replied. "I didn't think of one."

The mouse dug into the shavings. "He likes to hide," Grace said. "Let's call him Peekaboo."

"I like it," I said, hunkering down next to the cage. "Peekaboo, I see you."

"Just keep him in his cage," Mom said. "The last thing we need is an invisible mouse running around the house."

"I promise, Mom."

"Good. Now, you'll have to clean out the carrier. It looks like eliminations become visible once they're out."

"Good to know." Turning to Frank, Jr., I said, "Reason #2 for you to stay out of my bathroom. You may not be able to see me naked right now, but I don't want you walking in on me when I'm on the toilet."

"Don't worry," he said, "I don't want to see that, either."

******************************


I put Peekaboo's cage not far from my computer. I got a kick out of watching him either running around on his wheel or looking around at his new surroundings. "Bit of a change from that lab, huh?" I asked him.

There was a knock on the door, and Mom poked her head in. "How's it going in here?"

"My second draft looks good so far," I replied. "And Peekaboo is settling in."

"What does he look like?"

"He's white, with blue eyes. And he's totes adorbz."

"I'll take your word for that. Don't stay up too late."
111323311111112211.title: Returning home.

1113233111111122111.content:
The next morning, I cleaned out Peekaboo's cage, gave him fresh food and water, then took a shower. He was happy to see me. "Figured out this isn't like the lab, huh?" I asked him. "Yeah, I may have slowed down the search for an antidote, but, looking at you, I don't care so much."

Mom knocked, then poked her head in. "They've noticed your little friend is missing," she said. "They have no idea where he - Oh, my God!"

"What is it?"

"For a moment there, I... I saw Peekaboo!"

"You saw him?" My mind reeled. "What about now?"

"He's invisible again. But I did see him."

I looked at my new pet. "How did you do that?"

******************************


After breakfast, I brought Peekaboo to the kitchen table, and everyone looked at him and his cage. From their expressions, it was clear that they could all now see him. "What's going on?" Mom asked. "Why can we see him now? And how did he turn invisible again earlier?"

"It's just a guess," Dad replied. "But I'd say that Peekaboo's natural state is invisibility, now. But he can make himself visible, probably when he's most comfortable. Back at the lab, they were poking and prodding him all the time, so he was always afraid. But we treat him more like a pet than a test subject, so he can relax."

"Then my scream scared him," Mom said. "Do you realize what this means?"

"Grace can't bring him to show-and-tell?" Frank, Jr., asked.

"Much more than that," Dad said. "JJ, it means the answer to making you visible again is inside you right now. It may take a while, and it won't be permanent, but you can get to a point where you can be seen when you want to be."

"Okay," I said, "first, we record the podcast, then, we try to figure out how I can do this." Inside, though, I was jumping for joy. There was a chance, a real chance, that I could be visible again. I probably wouldn't be able to go back to school - one lockdown drill, and I would disappear - but I could hang out with my friends again.

I could hang out with Nick again.
1113233111111122111.title: A Surprise from Peekaboo

11132331111111221111.content:
After the podcast was recorded, and Izzy took it to edit and upload it, I went back to my room. There, Peekaboo watched me websurf while he munched seeds. "What's your secret, little guy?" Softly, I muttered. "I wish you could tell me. Is it the fact you're more relaxed, now that you aren't a lab mouse anymore?"

I figured that had to be at least part of it, and decided to try to find ways to relax myself. The first thing I tried was soft music, then sound ambience. Although it did help me to relax, I still couldn't see myself in the mirror. Sighing, I sat down, trying my best not to cry in frustration. "I'm so close, I can feel it." Tears falling, I whispered. "The answer is right in front of me, and I can't quite grasp it."

I spent a minute or two, sobbing out my frustration, before a squeak from Peekaboo caught my attention. I turned to him to find he was staring at me intently with a sad look in his eyes. It was like he somehow knew how I felt. Needing some comfort from someone, I opened the cage and offered my hand. Peekaboo scurried onto my hand and up my arm. He made himself comfortable on my shoulder and squeaked in my ear, making me giggle. "You silly mouse." Smiling, I said.

I began to pet Peekaboo, with him returning my affections by licking my hand and squeaking happily. I became so enthralled with bonding with him that I didn't hear a knock on my door. Dad peered in. "JJ, it's getting late, you should... "

I turned, hearing Dad, but became worried, as he didn't finish his sentence. Dad had a look of surprise on his face, making me worry more. "What's wrong?"

"For a moment, I thought I saw... " Dad began. He shook his head. "Never mind. It's getting late, you should get ready for bed. And put Peekaboo back in his cage, as only you and Grace can see him if he decides to vanish."

"Okay Daddy." Smiling, I said. "Goodnight."

As I put Peekaboo back into his cage, it didn’t click that Dad might have seen me for a moment. My mind was too calm and relaxed to think about it.
11132331111111221111.title: When answers are too close to see.

111323311111112211111.content:
The next morning, Grace and I went downstairs together. It was a routine we developed, since everyone could see her, but only she could see me.

As we sat down for breakfast, Mom asked, "How was your night?"

"Frustrating," I replied. "I'm sure that the key has to be being relaxed and calm, and feeling safe, but I can't seem to manage it the way Peekaboo can."

"I'd be surprised if you could," Mom said. "People from the university, and maybe the government, are after you. That isn't conducive to feeling safe. And you've been worried about how your friends, and your boyfriend, would react to your invisibility. If you're worried, getting calm is that much harder."

"Great," I said, "so it's impossible."

"Nobody said that, JJ," Dad replied. "Just that it would be hard."

"I understand your frustration, JJ," Mom said. "The words and the situation are new, but I've heard the emotion behind them before, from all of you kids."

"When was that?" Frank, Jr., asked.

"When you were learning to walk. First, you learned to crawl. Then, you learned to stand. Then, you learned to walk. But it wasn't a quick job for any of you. All three of you cried with despair every time you fell down. But you did learn. And then, when you fell, you just got up again, laughing. You older kids saw it with Grace, but you went through it all, too. You will be visible again, JJ. I'm sure of it."

"So am I," Dad added. "The key may be even closer than you realize."
111323311111112211111.title: The following morning.

1113233111111122111111.content:
About ten o'clock, Izzy and Mina came over. "Another J File for the streaming pleasure of listeners everywhere," Izzy said. "Mrs. J, do you think, once we're back in school, we could line up some merch? I'm sure we'd make back our investment in no time."

"I'll think about it," she replied. It gave me hope, since she had said the same thing before buying us the equipment that brought The J Files to the world.

"Come up to my room, guys," I said. "There's something I've gotta show you."

******************************


Once we were in my room, it didn't take long for the girls to figure out what I wanted to show them. "Where'd you get the mouse?" Mina asked. "And how does this one get along with the invisible one?"

"That's Peekaboo, right there," I replied, taking him out of his cage. "Turns out, he can make himself visible." I put him in Izzy's hands.

Peekaboo sniffed, and Izzy screamed. "Where'd he go?"

"He's right there," I replied, "in your hands." I took one of her fingers, and had her pet him. "Like I said, he knows how to make himself visible. The folks at the lab just never saw it." I collected Peekaboo from Izzy's hand and brought him to Mina.

In Mina's hands, Peekaboo again became visible. "How does he do it?" Mina asked.

"I think," I replied, "he makes himself visible when he feels safe and calm, something he never felt at the lab. I don't know why he turned invisible on Izzy."

"I do," Izzy said. "He smelled my cat."

"So peace of mind might be the key," Mina said. "Have you tried it?"

"I tried soft music and gentle sounds. No luck."

"Those things are just for the background," Mina said, "while you do something else. Yoga and meditation helped me manage my fears while I was waiting for the kidney transplant, and my doctors say it helped me heal afterwards. Wanna try it?"

I shrugged, though neither of them could tell. "I've got nothing to lose by trying."
1113233111111122111111.title: The Girls Come Over

choices: Mom helps me more with yoga.
A message on the tip line.
11132331111111221111111.content:
After putting Peekaboo back in his cage, I turned to Mina. "What's first?"

"Alright, the first thing you need to do is set an intention." Calmly, Mina said. "Dedicate your first practice to Peekaboo, who is obviously scared of the smell of Izzy's cat."

"So, I'm to focus on other people's worries?" Trying to understand, I asked.

"No, you focus on helping others with their worries." Serious, Mina said. "By helping others, believe it or not, you also help yourself."

"Anything I should know before I start?" Curious, I asked.

"You should wear comfortable clothes, like what I assume you have on now." Calmly, Mina replied. "Also, you're not going to nail all of the poses on the first day, so don't stress."

"Breathing is crucial." Serious, Izzy added. "Much like breathing for a runner."

"She means that you need to learn to control your breathing, so your heart beats at a more relaxed pace." Smiling, Mina explained. "A quick breathing pattern causes the heart to beat faster, and relaxation will be harder to grasp."

"Okay, let's start." smiling, I said.

Mina nodded. "Be forewarned, you're going to feel sore after your first lesson." Serious, she said. "Yoga and meditation is a training of the body as well as the mind."

With that, my first lesson began, with Mina having me sit Indian style, while she did the same sitting in front of me. She ran me through the numbers of finding my center and controlling my breathing.

Within an hour of the lesson, I was beginning to feel the soreness in my legs and back. Though the first lesson only lasted an hour and a half, I found it difficult to get myself to stand. "This is harder than I thought it would be."

Mina giggled. "I said the same thing after my first lesson." Bemused, she said. "Only this is just the beginning. You're going to be sore for a while, but the rewards really outweigh the discomfort." She walked to her purse and produced a small tube. "This is a muscle rub, it'll help with the soreness."

"I'll have Mom help me apply it." Accepting the tube, I said. "Same time tomorrow?"

Mina smiled. "Count on it." Kindly, she said. "Just keep practicing your breathing exercises, so we can move on to relaxing your mind and muscles."
11132331111111221111111.title: Yoga and Meditation

111323311111112211111112.content:
It didn't take Mom long to get the hang of rubbing my legs, even though she couldn't see them. After that, I relaxed and let the rub work its magic on my sore muscles.

When I could move again, I gave Peekaboo a little petting, then checked the response the latest episode was getting. To my surprise, there was already something on the tipline. I went to the door to my room. "Dad, we've got something."

He came running. "What is it?"

"You said you wanted to listen to anything that came in on the tipline." I clicked the message:

"I don't know who your source is, but Project Griffin isn't a figment of anybody's imagination. I've got the proof. Meet me tonight at the Whale, at 8:00. Come alone."


I turned to Dad. "What do you think?"

"I've heard my share of calls like that," he replied. "Either they have something to hide, or they want to get the other person out of hiding, in a situation where the caller is in complete control. With this case, I'm betting it's the latter."

"What do you think we should do?"

"This is way too dangerous for you to be where this person wants you. You hang back. I'll handle this. An undercover officer will pretend to be you, and we'll have backup out the wazoo. My lieutenant will understand."

"If it's on the up-and-up, you'll make sure I hear everything?"

"You don't even need to ask, pumpkin."
111323311111112211111112.title: A message on the tip line.

1113233111111122111111121.content:
I was sitting in the back of an unmarked van in the alley behind The Whale, a sports bar a block from the harbor. Dad was outside, talking with the rookie cop who would pose as me for the meet. Eventually the rookie cop walked off as Dad opened the van’s side door. Without even looking around for me, he said, “JJ, sweetie, I’m going to turn on the speakers, so you can hear everything that goes on inside.”

From my spot in the corner of the van, opposite him, I said, “Thanks, Dad.”

Now that he knew where I was, Dad looked at me and said, “Don’t worry, sweetie, we’ll figure this out.”

After turning on the speaker system, Dad closed the door, and I was once again alone inside the van. As a way to pass the time, I tried working on my meditation. I only barely paid attention to the voices on the speaker; after all, it was being recorded, so I could listen later.

As the minutes passed by, I started to feel a tingling sensation in my right hand. Looking down, I didn’t see anything out of the ordinary, until something reflecting off a monitor caught my eye. Looking closer, I was shocked to see that my thumb had become visible. Ecstatic, I was about to call Dad over the radio to tell him, when, suddenly, I heard a gunshot ring out over the speaker.
1113233111111122111111121.title: The Whale

choices: Another Round of Yoga and Meditation
11132331111111221111111211.content:
I hunched next to the speaker, listening for any indication of what had just happened, and for any word from Dad. With each second, my mind flooded with images of Dad's lifeless body.

Finally, I heard him say, "Are you alright?" and I breathed a sigh of relief.

"I'm okay," the rookie said. "You?"

"Hey," Dad said, "I didn't just have someone blow someone's head off right in front of me."

"Where'd he go?"

"He jumped into a car, and they took off. They could be anywhere. Wait here, I'll call it in. IAB will want to talk to you. Don't worry: besides me and everyone here, we've got it on tape."

Shortly after that, Dad came back to the van, and I gave him the biggest hug. "I was so scared, Daddy," I said.

"There was plenty to be scared of, kiddo," Dad replied. "Your mom is always telling me how much she's scared until I get home. And now you know what goes through my mind when I hear about you sticking your button nose into things."

******************************


A little over a half hour later, Internal Affairs showed up. Dad spent some time talking to them, then brought one of them to the van, to hear the tape. I huddled in a corner and listened, as well:

"You sure don't look like a teenager in - "

"Shhh! Do you want us to get kicked out of this place?"


I'll give her this, she did a passable imitation of me.

"Who's she supposed to be for this?" asked the IAB guy.

"She's standing in for my daughter. I didn't want her anywhere near this."

We turned our attention back to the tape:

"You really think this Project Griffin is the real deal?"

"I know it for a fact. They're trying to find the secret of invisibility. And I'm scared to death they might have found it."

"What do you think they'll do with it?"

"Imagine going through your usual routine: Showering, getting dressed, surfing the web. Doing whatever you do. And you don't know it, but you aren't alone: someone's in the room with you. And the reason you don't know they're there is because they're invisible. And that's the happy scenario."

"So, what's the unhappy scenario?"

"An invisible pandemic. People dropping like flies. And doctors are unable to stop it, because they can't even see what's doing it. Any world leader would give anything for the cure. Assuming they even want - "


And that was when the gunshot happened.

There was silence in the van for a whole minute. Then the Internal Affairs guy asked, "Are there any other copies of this?"

"No," Dad replied. "My plan had been to share this with JJ, but now I don't know. I wanted to scare her out of investigating, but not like this."

"Let me help you." And he hit Delete.

"What are you doing?"

"Saving your life. And possibly the lives of your wife and kids. Whoever did this thought absolutely nothing of killing one loose end in public. If they thought you knew what's worth killing to keep secret, they'd wipe you all out, and then watch the Hallmark Channel while you get buried."

Dad was ashen. "I hadn't thought of it like that."

******************************


That night, I had a cup of chamomile tea, and Mom still had to give me a sleeping pill. It was one thing to know people were looking for me: finding out they were willing to kill was a punch in the gut.
11132331111111221111111211.title: An Ominous Sign

111323311111112211111112112.content:
The next morning, I went into another round of yoga and meditation. Not to try to become visible, but to calm my still shaking nerves. "I had always wanted to sink my teeth into a big case, and I got it." Shaken, I muttered. "Be careful what you wish for, I guess."

"Everyone learns the hard way, pumpkin." Startling me, Dad said.

"Don't scare me like that." My voice quivering, I scolded. "I didn't see or hear you come into my room."

"Invisibility is relative, JJ." Calmly, Dad said. "I've been called the Phantom Detective more than once." He cracked a small grin. "Experience in sneaking around, and having an uncanny knowledge of the city, have their advantages."

"Phantom Detective... ?" Curious, I asked. Then it hit me. "You were the voice behind Ham Radio Investigations?!"

Dad nodded. "It was a lifetime ago, before the internet became widely available to the general public." Ruefully, he explained. "I would reach out to ham radio operators, truck drivers, anyone who could hear my voice, to help the police solve crimes."

"It was Ham Radio Investigations that inspired me to start The J Files." Softly, I said. "I never knew... "

"I, too, wanted to sink my teeth into a big case." Serious, Dad said. "I got my wish, and came close to getting killed, just as you are now."

"What are you telling me, Daddy?" Worried, I asked. "That I should just walk away from this, and be grateful I'm still alive?"

Dad shook his head, surprising me. "My father tried to forbid me, only I was already in too deep." Sadly, he said. "The villain I'd been tracking came after my entire family." He drew in a breath. "From then on, I swore that I wouldn't allow anyone to threaten my family again."

"So, what are you saying?" Softly, I asked.

"We catch these guys before they get the chance." Firmly, Dad replied. He dropped a large folder onto the desk. "Pull up everything you've got on this case, and we'll compare notes."

"Exactly what are we going to do?" Pulling up the files, I asked.

"You will be preparing another upload, while I fire up the old ham radio." Serious, Dad explained. "These guys will be looking for an update on your J Files site, but they won't expect it to be broadcast on Ham Radio Investigations... I still have a few loyal contacts out there."

I smiled at that, but was surprised when Dad smiled back. "I saw that smile."

I quickly turned to a mirror to see that my face was visible, for but a moment. I wanted to celebrate, but then was not the time. "Let's get to work."
111323311111112211111112112.title: Dad and I team up.

choices: Dad and I write up a broadcast.
1113233111111122111111121121.content:
Despite the danger behind it all, it was like a dream come true working on a criminal case with Dad. He and I went over every last detail from the beginning, from the tips I had received, to the evidence both he and I had gathered. Almost all of my evidence was photographs I had taken in various areas around the city.

"It wasn't just one college that was hit, it was several." Frowning, Dad said. "This little project is far bigger than it lets on."

"There were burglary attempts made in the lab wing of all these colleges." Shocked, I added. "Only how do we know they were all working on invisibility?"

"The name of the projects going on in each lab." Serious, Dad said. "The university you investigated had Project Griffin, another is working on something called Project Ghost, and another is working on a Project Myst." He shook his head. "It doesn't take a genius to put two and two together, once they figure out what one project is about."

"Do you think it may be an inside job?" Curious, I asked.

"It would have to be someone or some group who goes to all of the colleges." Calmly, Dad said. "It certainly narrows the list of likely suspects."

After a moment of thought, I gasped. "The janitors!"

"What about them?" Curious, Dad asked.

"I noticed all of the colleges were maintained by the same janitorial company." Serious, I explained. "The crook who threw that beaker at me was wearing the company's coveralls."

"Which explains how he was able to gain access to the lab." Frowning, Dad said. "He and his buddies must have caught on to what was being worked on, and saw a golden opportunity to make it big."

"Only the one who I caught trying to steal the formula either got greedy or sloppy." Softly, I said. "That forced him to act out of desperation."

"Likely a little bit of both." Serious, Dad said. "I doubt he knew he had the formula. Otherwise, he would have just run with it, rather than throwing it away."

"So we have a likely suspect." Serious, I said. "Where do we go from here?"

Dad smiled. "We write up a new file, then go to Ham Radio Investigations." Calmly, he said. "I always made my brodcasts sound like a story being unfolded. If we word things right, we just might get a few good tips on where these sticky-fingered janitors are going to strike next."
1113233111111122111111121121.title: Comparing notes.

11132331111111221111111211211.content:
Once we had it written down, Dad said, "Let's see if I can still do the voice." He cleared his throat a couple of times, then spoke in a lower, more raspy voice. "Testing, testing, 1, 2, 3. Alright, I think that's got it."

I got goosebumps. I had read descriptions of the Phantom Detective's voice, even heard one or two recordings, but I never imagined I would hear it directly from the source.

Switching on the ham radio, Dad began. "The Phantom Detective has returned, faithful listeners. I have been dormant for quite some time, but the tale I bring you now should be well worth the wait." And so he began, telling ham radio listeners what we had found.

It was amazing, listening to him work. I had co-written it, and I still sat mesmerized, waiting for the next detail to come. It's a good thing I wasn't trying to meditate or do yoga, because my heart was pounding in my ears.

Finally, he came to the conclusion, and I expected him to just give his sign-off and put the mic down. Instead, he said, "I know some of you have missed me out there, but take heart: there is a worthy successor out there. She has a podcast called The J Files, and I've never missed an episode. If you will listen to her, you will know why she has earned the respect of the Phantom Detective. And now, this story has ended. What happens next, well, that is up to you. This has been the Phantom Detective."

When he was through, he coughed several times, then said, in his real voice, "Damn, I forgot how hard it is to do that voice for an hour. What did you think, JJ?"

"Everybody says," I replied, "that you shouldn't meet your heroes. But I can't say I met my hero, because I grew up knowing everything about him, except that he was my hero." I hugged him and kissed him.
11132331111111221111111211211.title: Ham Radio Investigations.

choices: A warning over the ham radio.
111323311111112211111112112111.content:
Less than an hour after the broadcast, a reply came over the ham radio which Dad had hooked up to an old reel to reel recorder, to catch all the tips when they came in.

It was from a long-haul truck driver. "I have delivered a few strange loads to a lot of the colleges you mentioned, Phantom Detective." Serious, he said. "Nothing that would really raise red flags, but several times more than any college lab should need."

"That is strange." In his character voice, Dad replied. "Anything specific about the orders that might have caught your attention?"

"Just that I'm always getting complaints that some of it was missing, even when I specifically have the college count the order before I leave." Calmly, the driver said.

"Who counts the order?" Suspecting the answer, Dad pressed.

"The janitor on duty." Serious, the driver explained. "We suspect he's involved in the thefts at some level. My next lab shipment will be to East College; they're expanding their science wing."

"Thank you for the tip, loyal listener." Serious, Dad said. "You have done your part to put the brakes on corruption and crime."

"That's a big 10-4, Phantom Detective." Serious, the driver said. "Glad to hear you back on the air. We gone."

Dad cut off the mic, then turned in my direction, smiling. "We now have an idea where they will strike next." Softly, he said. "We need to get ready."

"You're not making me sit this one out?" surprised, I asked.

"You're in too deep for me to push you away now." Calmly, Dad said. "Let's go get the bad guys, and put an end to their stealing spree."
111323311111112211111112112111.title: There Is a Reply

1113233111111122111111121121111.content:
"Alright," Dad said, "let's go over everything."

The plan was fairly simple: "Our trucker friend will deliver what seems to be his scheduled load to East College," I said. "However, all the boxes will be dummies, with GPS tracking devices inside. When the maintenance engineer makes his move, we follow the signal, and catch all or most of the gang red-handed. I think we've got this, Daddy."

"There's no such thing as a foolproof plan, JJ," he replied. "Anything could go wrong between planning and execution." He smiled. "But it looks like everything we can control is under control."

And so we waited. To help us stay frosty, Dad played solitaire, while I went over Mina's notes for the next podcast. There were to be updates on previous cases, as well as a new mystery that a supporter on Patreon had tipped us off on. Now, however, I was adding a personal message, after the one that Dad had given on Ham Radio Mysteries.

Finally, the plan went into action. The GPS showed that the dummy shipment was underway, right on schedule. For now, all we could do was watch and wait.
1113233111111122111111121121111.title: Setting the Trap

15.content:
Jessica Joanna "JJ" Juspeczyk: Main character; 17; podcaster; becomes invisible
Frank Juspeczyk: JJ's father; police detective; supports his daughter
Amelia Juspeczyk: JJ's mother; architect; works from home; homeschools JJ after she turns invisible
Frank "Frankie" Juspeczyk, Jr.: 14; JJ's brother
Grace Juspeczyk: 3; JJ's sister
Izzy Kessler: 17; JJ's friend; assists on JJ's podcast
Mina Johnson: 17; JJ's friend; also assists on the podcast
Nick Connors: 17; JJ's boyfriend
Dr. Garrett: JJ's doctor; only adult outside the family trusted to know of JJ's invisibility
15.title: Cast of Characters

info.brief_description: JJ hasn't been seen lately. But she isn't missing: She's invisible.
info.description:
This is the story of JJ Juspeczyk, a teen podcaster who stuns her family and friends, and gives herself a pretty big shock, when she becomes invisible.

Of course, you gotta have rules:

1) No killing off the main character.
2) 1st person, past tense.
3) At least try to use good spelling and punctuation.
4) There should be a minimum of one paragraph per chapter.
5) Keep it PG-13. Nudity is fine. Strong language is okay, but don't overdo it. Sex is okay, but don't go into detail.
6) Check out my other interactives for a fuller idea of what to expect from me.

With that out of the way, let's get going.
info.pretty_title: If They Could See Me Now
